description: First attested in late Middle English circa 1425; from the French décerner, from the Latin dēcernō (“I decide, pronounce a decision”), from dē (“of, from, away from”) + cernō (“I separate, distinguish”), whence the English cern. In Old French, the forms of décerner were frequently conflated with those of descerner, discerner; the two verbs were not clearly distinguished until the 16th century; hence, in English also, decern is found with the sense discern.

verbs.description: decern (third-person singular simple present decerns, present participle decerning, simple past and past participle decerned)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) Decide; determine (a matter disputed or doubtful).
(transitive) Decree by judicial sentence. Now a technical term of Scottish judicature; the use of the word decerns being necessary to constitute a decree.
examples: He purſued Andrew Houſtoun upon his promiſe, to give him the like Sallary for the next year, and in abſence obtained him to be holden as confeſt and Decerned.

entries.meaning: Decree by judicial sentence that something be done.
Decree a person etc. to be or to do something by judicial sentence.  (in the phrase “to decern in”, obsolete) To mulct in by decree of court.
examples: He purſued Andrew Houſtoun upon his promiſe, to give him the like Sallary for the next year, and in abſence obtained him to be holden as confeſt and Decerned.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) Distinguish or separate by their differences (things that differ, one thing from another).
See distinctly (with the eyes or the mind); distinguish (an object or fact); discern.
